column1: Onalaska is a city in La Crosse County
column4: 736 at the 2010 census. It borders the larger La Crosse
column6: and is a part of the La Crosse-Onalaska
column7: WI-MN Metropolitan Area.Onalaska is built on a slightly elevated ridge above the Black River.  Natural areas include both river bottom land and high
column9: scenic bluffs. A man-made reservoir at the city's western edge is known as Lake Onalaska. Onalaska is known as "The Sunfish Capital of the World."

column1: The original village (now city) was platted by Thomas G. Rowe (New York) and John C. Laird (Pennsylvania) in 1851. In its early days
column2: lumbering and related industries served as a basis for its economy.The name for the city comes from the poem
column4: by the Scottish poet Thomas Campbell. The original spelling of the name in Campbell's poem was "Oonalaska" (an Aleutian island and fishing village).Other places named Onalaska are in Arkansas (now defunct)
column5: Texas and Washington; they are historically linked to one another through the lumber industry. In Alaska
column6: the modern day city of Unalaska and Unalaska Island are linked to the Onalaskas through Thomas Campbell's poem. Unalaska is the original Oonalaska or Onalaska or "Ounalashka" (Russian spelling) immortalized by Campbell.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.73 square miles (27.79 km2)
column3: of which 10.13 square miles (26.24 km2) is land and 0.60 square miles (1.55 km2) is water.Onalaska lies immediately north of La Crosse
column4: on the Black River. It is the second largest city in La Crosse County.

column1: Named streams within the current corporate limits of the city include the Black River
column2: the La Crosse River and Sand Lake Coulee Creek. In the 1930s

column6: and several smaller ponds in the Black River bottoms area.

column1: Brice Prairie is an urban reserve area within the City of Onalaska
column2: located below the ridge on which most of the city is situated. It lies to the northwest of the city's current northern border
column3: and is directly on Lake Onalaska.
